awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Insights into Tropical Pacific Climate from Paleoproxy Data Assimilation into an Intermediate Complexity Dynamical Model
awd_abstract_narration:
This project broadly seeks to reconstruct and interpret the state of the tropical Pacific over the last millennium in response to radiative forcing.  This will be accomplished by assimilating high-resolution paleo-proxies from corals and trees into a dynamical El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) model.

Dynamically informed paleo-reconstructions will be studied to address the following science questions: (i) how does the tropical Pacific respond to external radiative forcing (ERF); (ii) does ENSO exhibit regime-like behavior and is ENSO irregularity primarily due to chaotic or to noise-driven dynamics; (iii) how has ENSO varied in the past; and (iv) can a dynamical ENSO model improve paleo-proxy reconstructions of the tropical Pacific. 

These questions have implications for predictability and decadal variability and are relevant to understanding ENSO and its impacts, past, present and future. Adding information into paleoclimate reconstructions from a dynamical model of ENSO with documented predictive skill is a novel approach and may enhance interpretation of Tropical Pacific proxy records. 

The potential Broader Impacts include improved understanding of ENSO behavior over time, support of undergraduate students in the research project, and outreach to the public through well-established outreach efforts at Columbia University and the University of Maryland.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
El Nino - Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is the most powerful interannual climate variability mode, with global climate and economic impacts. Incidentally, it is the only one whose predictions with lead times of about a year have demonstrable skill. These properties make ENSO variability important as a major object of climate research and an ever-present phenomenon societies must negotiate. Thus, improving ENSO predictions and our knowledge of past ENSO variability is necessary. The latter is relevant to the former because of the shortness of instrumental climate records. 

Longer records come from long-living species, like corals or trees, that grow annual layers with physical or biological characteristics reflecting their environmental conditions. There has been much effort to reconstruct past climate from such records using purely statistical methods or to assimilate them into global coupled general circulation models (GCMs). Here, we focused on the ENSO-generating engine - the tropical Pacific ocean-atmosphere system.

Zebiak-Cane intermediate coupled model for ENSO prediction was the first dynamical model to issue a successful forecast of an El Nino event [1]. Its current operational version, LDEO5 [2], remains competitive and issues successful operational forecasts despite being much simpler than GCMs (Figure 1).

M.N.Evans, a colleague from the University of Maryland, collaborated with us on this project, selecting marine climate proxies from global databases that had a significant statistical relationship with the tropical Pacific climate. The relationship was established using linear regression for the 1920-2000 calibration period with local temperature and precipitation for the records within the model domain. For those outside, the relationship was established with the leading Principal Components of temperature and precipitation in the model domain or with the closest domain gridpoint. Figure 2 shows the locations of the marine records we used and their dependencies on the model-simulated variables.  

A different strategy was used to assimilate data from trees:a network of 1239 tree-ring chronologies from circum-Pacific land areas that are known to receive El Nino-generated rainfall (Figure 3A), were selected from the global tree-ring record database, further screened statistically, and used to perform statistical reconstructions of the tropical Pacific boreal winter (December-January-February, or DJF, averages) sea surface temperatures (SST). Each of the attempted reconstructions going from 1100, 1200, ..., 1800 CE to 2000 CE (called R11, R12,..., and R18, respectively) only used the chronologies that spanned the entire reconstruction interval (see Figure 3B for R15 predictors' pool). A reconstruction extending back to 1500 (R15), based on 242 tree-ring chronologies, showed exceptional skill; the one expanding back to 1100 (R11) used 81 chronologies and was the longest one with acceptable skill, accounting for 50% of the validation period variance [3]. We assimilated the first PCs of these reconstructions.

Using a reduced space (RS) approach to data assimilation [4], we produced RS versions of optimal interpolation (OI), Kalman filter, and optimal smoother (OS); these differ from each other by the degree of the model's use in the solution, but each assimilation product provides a monthly multivariate description of the system (Figure 4). Figures 5AB show equatorial Pacific DJF SST variability from  RSOI and RSOS assimilations of marine records. Data assimilation products present non-zero anomalies whenever any observations are available. However, when observations are absent for an extended period, as it happened during 1464-1571 in our marine records data set (Figure 5D), the assimilation tends towards the climatological mean, which here, for anomalies, is zero.

As expected, RSOS retains more variance in the SST estimates than the  RSOI. When the number of observations is small, spurious bursts of equatorial SST variability may occur in the RSOS assimilation of marine records (1600-1610, ~1430, etc). However, assimilating a tree-ring reconstruction with marine data (Figure 5C) fixes this problem.

To check the reconstructions against independent data, we use the chronology of El Nino events compiled by William Quinn [5]. Exploiting the large-scale impacts of El Nino events, he analyzed historical documents and other publications to identify the years and strengths of El Ninos. Figure 6 shows a similar level of agreement with Quinn's ratings for separate RSOS assimilations of marine records and R15 tree-based reconstruction. Assimilating these two sources of paleodata in a single run improves the agreement with Quinn's ratings (Figure 7). The scatterplots in Figure 8 confirm this conclusion.

We designed and demonstrated at work a relatively inexpensive data assimilation system that successfully combined annually-resolved paleoclimate data with model dynamics, repeating multi-century data assimilation runs for five data set combinations of R11, R15, and marine records. All data assimilation results were stored to become publicly available as a useful resource for research and education.  

Notes

[1] M.A.Cane et al., Nature, 321:827-832, 1986.

[2]  D.Chen et al., Nature, 428:733-736, 2004.

[3]  E.R.Cook, M.A.Cane,  Geophysical Research Letters, 51, e2024GL109759, 2024.

[4]  A.Kaplan et al., J. Geophys Res., 102:27835-27860, 1997. 

[5]  W.Quinn, Bulletin de l'Institut Francais d'Etudes Andines, 22(1):13-34, 1993
